Title.evidence: A Randomised Controlled Trial of Ventilation Modes in Pediatric Thoracic Surgery

Trial_Design.evidence: randomly assigned to either the PCV-VG group (n=42) or the volume-controlled ventilation (VCV) group (n=41)

Participants.evidence: Eighty-three children aged 6 months to 18 years, classified as ASA I-III, undergoing video-assisted thoracoscopic lobectomy with OLV at Hunan Children’s Hospital, China

Intervention.evidence: randomly assigned to either the PCV-VG group (n=42) or the volume-controlled ventilation (VCV) group (n=41)

Objective.evidence: This randomised controlled trial assessed whether pressure-controlled ventilation-volume guaranteed (PCV-VG) reduces intrapulmonary shunt (Qs/Qt) and ventilator-induced lung injury (VILI)

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was Qs/Qt, measured at five time points during surgery

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated with allocation concealed in opaque envelopes

Blinding.evidence: Data collectors and surgical staff were blinded

Number_Randomised.evidence: randomly assigned to either the PCV-VG group (n=42) or the volume-controlled ventilation (VCV) group (n=41)

Result_Outcome.evidence: The PCV-VG group demonstrated a significant reduction in median Qs/Qt during OLV (18.2 to 12.7 at T2, 11.4 to 9.1 at T3, p<0.0001). Compared to VCV, PCV-VG improved oxygenation (higher PaO2, PaO2/FiO2), reduced airway pressure (25 cmH2O to 20 cmH2O at T2, p<0.0001), and lowered PPCs incidence (38.5% to 7.3%, OR 0.13, 95% CI: 0.03–0.50, p=0.001). The duration of postoperative mechanical ventilation was shorter in the PCV-VG group (120 min to 110 min, difference 20, 95% CI 0 to 40, p=0.036)
